questions.text:
Choose whether sentences are T-True or F-false
1. PR interval = AV conduction time
2. QT interval = ventricular action potential except plateau
3. ST interval = plateau of action potential of ventricle
questions.solution:
PR interval is time taken for impulse to travel from atria to ventricle

QT interval is time taken for ventricular action potential with plateau

ST interval= is time taken for plateau of action potential of ventricle

Table 1: ECG Interval


Topic: ECG

Clinical question

Reference: Ganong's Review of medical Physiology, 24 th Edition, Chapter 29, page number 526

questions.text:
Choose whether sentences are T-True or F-false
1. Digitalis inhibits Na K pump
2. Digitalis prolongs AV conduction time
3. Digitalis is used in systolic Heart failure
4. Digitalis can be use treat atrial fibrillation
questions.solution:
Digitalis inhibits Na K pump as main effect

Digitalis prolongs AV conduction time by blocking conduction

Digitalis is used in systolic Heart failure as it raises Ca++ availability inside cell

Digitalis can be use treat atrial fibrillation as it prolongs AV conduction time


Topic: Cardiac muscle

Clinical question

Reference: Ganong's Review of medical Physiology, 24th Edition, Chapter 29, page number 524

questions.text:
Choose whether sentences are T-True or F-false
1. Ventricular systole starts near the beginning of R wave
2. Ventricular systole ends after T wave
3. Ventricular systole begins with high frequency sound
4. Ventricular systole shows v wave on JVP
questions.solution:
Ventricular systole starts near the end of R wave

Ventricular systole ends after T wave

Ventricular systole begins with low frequency sound

Ventricular systole shows a and c wave on JVP


Topic: Cardiac cycle

Very Important Question

Reference: Ganong's Review of medical Physiology, 24th Edition, Chapter 29, page number 539-543

choices.text: Acid induced released of motilin from the small intestine
Acid induced release of secretin from the small intestine
Distension induced release of glucagon from the small intestine
Fat induced release of cholecystokinin from the small intestine

questions.text: An obese woman presents to the emergency department with right upper quadrant, pain, nausea and vomiting. The ultrasound images showed gallstones with cystic duct obstruction. Which of the following is the primary physiological stimulus of gallbladder contraction in the digestive period
questions.solution:
Food in the small intestine from the emptying of the gallbladder. This is due to the release of fat induced cholecystokinin.

Secretin stimulates pancreatic HCO3 secretion. Glucagon is involved in nutrient metabolism and motilin is an inter-digestive hormone responsible for migrating motor complex activity.

Topic: Gastrointestinal_Gall bladder

Important question

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, Page number 443

questions.text:
A 5 feet tall man looks like the following



The Image best represents which of the following
questions.solution:
Excessive growth hormone after adolescence cause acromegaly. Enlargement is seen in bones of hands and feet and membranous bones such as forehead, nose, lower jaw because their growth does not cease at adolescence.

Gigantism occurs when excess growth hormone is present before adolescence. The epiphyses have not yet closed and hence the giant is about 8 feet tall.

Dwarfism results from deficiency of growth hormone during childhood. Such a person does not have the bodily development of an adult.

Down's syndrome is characterized by flat round face with small nose, mouth and ears.

Topic: Endocrine_ Pituitary

Clinical question

Reference: Guyton and Hall textbook of medical physiology, 14th edition, page number 937

questions.text: In post-menopausal woman physiologically most suitable combination is________
questions.solution:
Due to loss of FSH responsive ovarian follicles there is no steroidogenesis and low estrogen and progesterone, and loss of negative feedback on FSH and LH so blood level of FSH, LH is raised

Topic: Endocrine_Menopause

questions.text:

1. Thyroid gland is not essential for life
2. Thyroid gland output is predominant T3 than T4
3. Thyroid gland shows reabsorption lacunae in inactive state
questions.solution:
Thyroid gland is not essential for life as it can be removed without much metabolic effect

Thyroid gland output is predominant T4(pro-hormone) than T3

Thyroid gland shows reabsorption lacunae in active state due to use of colloid for secretion

Topic: Endocrine_thyroid hormones

choices.text: Acts on GR receptors to enhance its receptivity for gastrin
Increases the release of secretin from duodenum

questions.text: A patient with arthritis being treated with NSAIDs presents with pain in epigastrium that goes away on eating. The patient was diagnosed with peptic ulcer. How do NSAIDs cause peptic ulcer?
questions.solution:
Drugs like aspirin and NSAID inhibit the production of prostaglandins and consequently decrease mucus and bicarbonate secretion. This exposes the gastric mucosa to the acid that causes ulceration.

Topic: Gastric secretion

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, Page number 433

questions.text: Arrange osmolarity of urine in descending order where x= iso-osmotic urine, y= Diabetes Insipidus z= Maximum Vasopressin
questions.solution:
With Vasopressin, water reabsorption is maximum urine osmolarity being maximum, in DI, with no vasopressin water reabsorption is zero, and osmolarity is maximum, reverse is true about urine volume.

Clinical Question

questions.text:
Choose whether sentences are T-True or F-false
1. Renal medulla has low pO2 Value than cortex
2. Renal medulla has high blood flow than cortex
3. Renal medulla is least prone to hypoxia in kidney
4. Renal medulla has less metabolic need than cortex
questions.solution:
Renal medulla has low(15) pO2 Value than cortex(50)

Renal medulla has low blood flow than cortex

Renal medulla is more prone to hypoxia in kidney due to low pO2

Renal medulla has more metabolic need than cortex as active transport ensues

Topic: Renal blood flow

Very Important question

Reference: Ganong's Review of medical Physiology, 24 th Edition, Chapter 37, page number 678

choices.text: A is true R is wrong
R is true A is wrong
Both A and R are true and A is explained by R
Both A and R are true and A is not explained by R

questions.text:
A- Normally less than 100 mg proteins are filtered in urine in a day with trace of albumin

R- Albumin has 7 nm molecular size
questions.solution:
Proteins are largely absent in urine in normal individuals however the reason for albumin is not size but its negative charge that is repelled by negatively charged Glomerular basement membrane. Pores are 8 nm in size so that is not the main cause.

Topic: Renal filtration

Clinical question

Reference: Ganong's Review of medical Physiology, 24th Edition, Chapter 37, page number 674

questions.text:
Choose whether sentences are T-True or F-false
1. Carotid bodies have O2 sensitive K+ channels that produce more K+ efflux with hypoxia
2. Carotid bodies receive 20 ml blood/gm/min
3. Carotid bodies meet oxygen demand by dissolved oxygen only
questions.solution:
Carotid bodies have ATP sensitive K+ channels that produce more K+ efflux with hypoxia

Carotid bodies receive 20 ml blood/gm/min(2000 ml/100 gm/min) - highest blood flow among all organ/tissue in the body per 100 gm basis

Carotid bodies meet oxygen demand by dissolved oxygen only due to high pO2 and less demand

Topic: Chemical regulation of respiration

questions.text:

VC=4600 ml, IC=3100 ml and RV= 1200 ml
questions.solution:
FRC=ERV+RV=(VC-IC)+ RV=(4600-3100)+1200=2700 ml

questions.text:
Choose whether sentences are T-True or F-false
I - Ammonium chloride ingestion leads to metabolic alkalosis
II - Breathing 7% CO2 produce Respiratory acidosis III- 3 week residence at 4000 m height produces respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
I - Ammonium chloride ingestion leads to metabolic alkalosis as it releases HCl acid

II - Breathing 7% CO2 produce Respiratory acidosis as it converts to H2CO3

III - 3 week residence at 4000 m height produces respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation

Topic: Acid base balance

Reference: Ganong's Review of medical Physiology, 24 th Edition, Chapter 36, page number 647

questions.text: A 50-year-old female was found to have a decreased GFR. The effects of which of the following is most likely like the cause
questions.solution:
Endothelin constricts the renal blood vessels thus reducing blood flow and GFR.

All the other options decrease renal vascular resistance and this increase the GFR

Topic: GFR

questions.text:
Choose correct cause of anemia from the following blood indices
Age 4 years old male, MCHC-30%, MCV-75 fL
questions.solution:
Question is about Morphological types of anemia and Red blood cell indices leading to cause of anemia. Blood indices shows MCHC more than 25 that is cut off and MCV less than 80 cut off so it is normochromic microcytic anemia that is due to chronic infections.

Topic: Anemia

Clinical Question

Reference:

1. Ganong's Review of medical Physiology, 26 th Edition, Chapter 31, page number 547

2. Textbook of Physiology by Dr AK Jain, Volume I, chapter 8, Page number 71

questions.text:
Statements related to human Insulin are given below. Which statement(s) is/are correct about genetically engineered Insulin?
a. Pro-hormone insulin contain extra stretch of C-peptide.
b. A-peptide and B-peptide chains of insulin were produced separately in E.coli, extracted and combined by creating disulphide bond between them.
c. Insulin used for treating Diabetes was extracted from Cattles and Pigs.
d. Pro-hormone Insulin needs to be processed for converting into a mature and functional hormone.
questions.solution:
Option (b) is the correct answer as genetically engineered insulin has A-peptide and B-peptide chains of insulin that are produced separately in E.coli, then they are extracted and combined by creating disulphide bond between them.

Topic: Insulin

Clinical Question

Reference:

  1. Guyton and Hall .Textbook of Medical Physiology.14th edition. Page.number 974.
  2. Rodwell et al .Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry. 31st edition.

choices.text: Blocks the release of ACh from presynaptic membrane
Destruction of ACh in the NM junction
Promotes ACh release from the presynaptic membrane

questions.text:
The x-ray examination of the esophagus of a patient shows the following picture


A diagnosis of achalasia cardia was made. The patient was started with botulinum toxin. What is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin that helps prevent this condition
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin acts on synaptobrevin, syntaxin and SNAP 25. It causes flaccid paralysis by blocking the release of ACh at the neuromuscular junction. Local injection of small doses of botulinum toxin is used in treatment of muscle hyperactivity.

Topic: Upper GI physiology

She also has an increased basal body temperature
The increase in temperature is due to
questions.solution:

The fern like pattern of cervical mucus indicates ovulation

Topic: Progesterone

Clinical Question

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, Page number 414

questions.text: Considering this as is flowchart of genesis of acquired immunity give F in figure?
questions.solution:
1. An antigen-presenting cell (depicted here as a macrophage, but other cell types, including dendritic cells, are important) ingests and partially digests an antigen, then presents part of the antigen along with MHC peptides (in this case, MHC II peptides on the cell surface).
  2. An "immune synapse" forms with a naive CD4 T cell, which is activated to produce IL-2.
  3. IL-2 acts in an autocrine fashion to cause the cell to multiply, forming a clone.
  4. The activated CD4 cell may promote B cell activation and the proliferation of plasma cells that produce antibodies or it may activate a cytotoxic CD8 cell. The CD8 cell can also be activated by forming a synapse with an MCH I antigen-presenting cell. MHC, major histocompatibility complex.

Topic: Immunity

Very Important Question

Reference: Ganong's Review of medical Physiology, 24 th Edition, Chapter 3, page number 72

questions.text: A patient presented with sleep apnea does not show increase in ventilation upon increasing paCO2 but ventilation is decreased during hyperoxia. What is the cause of apnea
questions.solution:
Central chemoreceptor play a role in responding to changes in+ in CSF brought about by change in arterial pCO2. The failure to increase ventilation indicates dysfunction of central chemoreceptor. Peripheral receptors are stimulated by hypercapnia, hypoxia, and acidemia.

Topic: Sleep apnea

Clinical question

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, Page number 629

questions.text: Which of the factor is responsible for the following change in Hb-O2 dissociation curve
questions.solution:
The curve is shifted to right meaning the affinity of Hb for O2 has reduced and a higher pO2 is required for Hb to bind to a given amount of O2.

The conditions that decrease the oxygen affinity and promote dissociation of O2 and Hb are:

  • Acidity
  • Raised temperature
  • Higher CO2 concentration
  • 2, 3-BPG

These factors are present in the tissues and facilitate oxygen delivery to them.

Topic: Transport of O2
